prompt.body: Put the next events in the right chronological order.

content.body: Shortly after Hitler came into power Jewish shops were boycotted
Night of the Broken Glass happened, Germans attacked and looted Jewish properties.
Almost immediately after the Treaty of Versailles the 'Stab-in-the-back'-myth became popular.
German Jews, rich and poor, were suspected of causing the Economical Crisis.
Neurenberg Laws proclaimed German Jews were officially as second-class citizens.

heading.content: CrashCourse: The Holocaust, Genocide and Mass Murder of WWII

items.content: Most parts of this Wiki-assignment are related to the CrashCourse (below). Watch the fragment before continuing with the questions.

items.caption: [13:38] CrashCourse: The Holocaust, Genocide and Mass Murder of WWII

prompt.body: The next words are mentioned explicitely in the CrashCourse, but what do they mean?

content.body: Special German forces who took the lead in the mass murders against 'unworthy' people like Jews and others.
The 'news' about the extermination were told from one to another among the Jewish population.
Massacre of Jews by their Polish fellow citizens in 1940, one of the early stages of the Holocaust.
The German invasion of the Soviet-Union in 1941.
German extermination camp built in Poland in 1941 to solve the Jewish Question.
With help of the Polish resistance the Jews were openly revolting against the Germans.
Action undertaken against disabled people to save the purity of the German race.
Attempt of Jewish prisoners in the extermination camp to destroy as much as they could.
Series of mass executions on Polish military officers and intelligentsia carried out by the Soviet-Union (1940).
Meeting of high-ranked German officials who decided to start with the construction of extermination camps.
According to the racial ideas of the Nazi's, the lowest 'untermenschen': the Russian communists.
Hebrew name for the genocide at the Jewish population during the Second World War.

prompt.body: Match the fragments of the CrashCourse with the right themes.

content.body: Entering and daily life in a the camps
The German occupation of Poland and the start of ethnic cleansing
Creating the Holocaust, or: growing needs for extermination camps

prompt.body: Match the labels with the photos about the Holocaust.

content.body: One day after liberation a group prisoners pose outside a camp.
Geman citizens visiting the crematoriums after the defeat of Nazi-Germany
A Jewish boy surrenders after the Warsaw Revolt (1943).
The arrival of Hungarian Jews at 'die Rampe' in Auschwitz.
Present-day entrance of Auschwitz with the sign: 'Arbeit macht Frei'
Pre-war genocide, Aktion T-4 exterminated the mentally ill.
A member of the Einsaztgruppe murdering a woman and het child.
An overcrowded barrack with men in an extermination camp.

Complete the text from the first part of the CrashCourse [00:00-01:50]:

Today, we're going to talk about the , which was an integral part of Nazism in World. War II. The of the Holocaust -millions of Jewish people were systematically murdered- shows humanity at its most depraved. And we've thought a lot about how much footage to show from the camps where so many millions were condemned to death, and we've decided not to have a Thought Bubble in today's episode. But we will be showing some archival footage, not least because disinformation campaigns throughout the last seventy years have sought to minimize or outright deny that the Holocaust happened.

Maybe there's no countering such -the evidence of the Holocaust is vast, including hundreds of thousands of witness accounts, testimony from war crimes trials, and extensive documentation by the Nazis themselves of their attempts to systematically eliminate. Jewish people from the world- and also others deemed , including disabled people,. Roma people, many Slavs, Communists, and LGBT people.

But we think it is important to try to tell the truth, both in what we say and in what we show. Some maintain that the Holocaust is -an outsized phenomenon beyond ordinary concepts of . And in some ways that's true, but it ignores the centuries of anti-Semitism that laid the groundwork for the of Jewish people that intensified in the 20th century.

It is critical that we remember the horrors of the holocaust. History is, in the broadest sense, collective memory, and as Holocaust survivor Elie Wiesel has written, "Without memory, there would be no civilization, no society, no future." And so let us try to remember.

prompt.body: Put the events in the right chronological order with help of the CrashCourse [01:50-05:33].

content.body: Wannsee Conference: Nazi-Germany decided to set up extermination camps
Operation Barbarossa, the German invasion of the Soviet-Union
Beginning of the T4-Aktion, the murder of German disabled people
Polish Jews gathered in the Warsaw ghetto
Invasion of Poland, start of WWII

Are the statements based on the next part [05:33-11:45] true or false?

True / False German soldiers who took part in the Holocaust were allowed to resign and given other tasks.

True / False Obeying authority is the foremost important motivation for taking part in mass killing of Jews.

True / False The Nazi's did a lot of efforts to conceal the purposes of the extermination camps.

True / False Jews could survive by preserving their humanity and by helping others.

True / False The Soviet-Union didn't commited mass murder after it attacked Poland in 1939.

True / False Some Eastern European people participated in the mass executions in the Soviet-Union, because they hated Jews, Russians and communist.
